questions.question_text: A penetration tester used an ASP.NET web shell to gain access to a web application, which allowed the tester to pivot in the corporate network. Which of the following is the MOST important follow-up activity to complete after the tester delivers the report?

discussion.content: E. this was on the exam

comments.content:
But the questions says "After" delivering the report. Wouldn't those attestations be within the report? That rules out E. 

Obtaining client acceptance is one of the first steps.

Removing shells and leaving everything "as you found it" would be the most important --Follow up-- activity

discussion.content:
Read the question very carefully as it says 'Which of the following is the MOST important follow-up activity to complete after the tester delivers the report'

A. Removing shells (Tester must do this prior to Finish the test)
B. Obtaining client acceptance (Tester must do this prior to Start the test)
C. Removing tester-created credentials (Tester must do this prior to Finish the test)
D. Documenting lessons learned (This step commence once everything is completed)
E. Presenting attestation of findings (This is the answer)

The answer is 'E'

Selected Answer: E
looks good to me

CertMaster says.
After finishing your PenTest and writing the report, you should plan to have a discussion with the client about the findings in the report.
Gaining the client's acceptance is of paramount importance, as they will not automatically be satisfied with your report just because you have written one

The answer is A
• Delete any new files you created from the affected systems.
• Remove any credentials or accounts you created from the affected systems.
• Restore any original configurations you modified.
• Restore any original files that you modified or otherwise compromised.
• Restore any log files you deleted.
• Restore any original log files you modified or otherwise compromised.
• Remove any shells, RATs, or other backdoors from the affected systems.
• Remove any additional tools you may have left on the affected systems.
• Purge any sensitive data exposed in plaintext.
• Restore a clean backup copy of any apps that you compromised.

comments.content: Cleanup would include A and C, hence any of them would be wrong answer.
Yep, this is it. I don't care what other say, I just finished an 11 hour course on Udemy and the last chapter includes cleanup activities even after the report has been handed over.

discussion.content:
From the book:

You have finished your report and have given it to the client. There are still a few things you need tomake sure have been taken care of before you can consider the case closed. This includes any cleanup tasks to put everything back as it was when you started, getting client acceptance and attestation of your findings, and identifying any lessons learned during the process and any follow-up actions that need to be performed.

Post-Engagement Cleanup TasksIn any case where an exploit will destabilize a live production system, you should be cleaning updirectly after. However, for everything else, you can wait until the report has been handed off tobegin your cleanup tasks. The purpose of these tasks is to ensure that there are no artifacts left overthat an attacker could exploit or that could lead to more risk than the organization is willing totolerate.

Answer is correct. E.
Once the report has been delivered, debriefing begins which you will need to provide attestation and supporting evidence of the findings. This is done AFTER the report has been delivered. A and C are done during Post-engagement cleanup, and B and D are just benefits of meeting face-to-face with the customer after the test. E, however, is necessary and MOST important.

comments.content:
Every single one of these answers are done after delivering the report. After a report has been delivered:
1. Post clean up. A&C
2. Client acceptance - Sign off saying you have completed the test.
3. Administrative tasks
3a. Follow up and retesting- Not on our answer list
3b. Attestation of findings - Optional for the client and most likely asked for if the test was for compliance.
3c. Lessons Learned - PenTest team meeting for after action reporting.

WIth all that being A & C are both huge security risks if left in place and should be eliminated since they both pose a potential risk. (D) is something that doesn't necessarily effect the pentest that was just preformed so this one is concentrating on the next test and future tests for the team. Between B & D I personally would go with B obtaining client acceptance. Reason for this is the client is agreeing to the results and findings, signing that they are satisfied and the test was completed properly. Many times attestation of findings are dismissed because the customer is satisfied with what has already been presented during testing and the report. This is just my 2 cents though.

more like they should be all done before delivering the report?

gonna have to agree with b
totally agree. B is the answer

Nope, https://ibm-learning.udemy.com/course/pentestplus/learn/lecture/11067692#overview (you may not be able to access if you are not employed by IBM) confirms that cleanup activities such as removing shells are done afterwards.

Although you are right in that it could be used by other attackers, you would not remove shells AFTER you deliver the report. Once the report has been delivered, debriefing begins which you will need to provide attestation and supporting evidence of the findings. Pay close attention to the wording of these questions. The answer is E.

discussion.content: A. the shell could be used by other hackers.

Selected Answer: D
looks good to me

D.

In software engineering, a WAR file (Web Application Resource) is a file used to distribute a collection of JAR-files, JavaServer Pages, Java Servlets, Java classes, XML files, tag libraries, static web pages (HTML and related files) and other resources that together constitute a web application.

The pentester can upload code for a web shell.

D. 

A. /etc/shadow makes no sense and it won't be in the doc root of Tomcat and the WAR file injection isn't going to solve that. Tomcat's user won't have perms to /etc/shadow either.
B. Monitor network traffic? This is gibberish in the context of this WAR file and/or Tomcat.
C. SSH has jack all to do with Tomcat credentials. 
D. This one seems probable as this WAR injection would absolutely be within the concept scope of generating a web shell on a web server.
is it C ?

comments.content: no, once you get on a box you'll want to establish persistence

questions.question_text: A penetration tester has discovered through automated scanning that a Tomcat server allows for the use of default credentials. Using default credentials, the tester is able to upload WAR files to the server. Which of the following is the MOST likely post-exploitation step?

choices.D: Install web shell on the server.
choices.C: Connect via SSH using default credentials.
Migration of the shell to another process

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
looks good to me

comments.content: Local eoP i menat not RCE ...

discussion.content:
i think it's d:
The Question is asking us to elevate priviledges on the maschine we have acces to.
Including a picture of File permission !

A: Kerberoasting make no sense for LOCAL RCE, 
B: Excluding the recent Hivemare vullnerabillity you are not able to retrieve the SAM als normal User.
C.) Migrating shell to another process is something you need to do with meterpreter. But no indication of meterpreter usage nor helps this elevating your privileges.

So i think D: would be the best guess:
You can see that "Everyone" has Full Access to some "software.exe" that is located on the pc.
So we can modify or replace this binary and hope that it is executed as Service with Sytems rights.
The answer is C
is right?

questions.question_text: A penetration tester is performing a wireless penetration test. Which of the following are some vulnerabilities that might allow the penetration tester to easily and quickly access a WPA2-protected access point?

comments.content: I agree with you you have todo A before you can even do B or D and C is wrong unless it's suppose to be WPS instead of WEP then in which case that would be the fastest

discussion.content: The answer is A. Deauth Attacks are the fastest and easiest ways to obtain the four-way handshake and then cracking it.

Selected Answer: A
looks good to me
Correct answer is A
A. this was on the exam

A.https://www.krackattacks.com/
Our main attack is against the 4-way handshake of the WPA2 protocol. This handshake is executed when a client wants to join a protected Wi-Fi network, and is used to confirm that both the client and access point possess the correct credentials (e.g. the pre-shared password of the network). At the same time, the 4-way handshake also negotiates a fresh encryption key that will be used to encrypt all subsequent traffic. Currently, all modern protected Wi-Fi networks use the 4-way handshake. This implies all these networks are affected by (some variant of) our attack. For instance, the attack works against personal and enterprise Wi-Fi networks, against the older WPA and the latest WPA2 standard, and even against networks that only use AES. All our attacks against WPA2 use a novel technique called a key reinstallation attack (KRACK):
agree with A when it's talking about WPA2..

I think C is the correct answer.
Because, the question asks for the vulnerabilities. I would say "Weaknesses in the implementation of Wi-Fi Protected Setup (WPS)" enables to brute forcing to recover 8 digit pins quickly and easily. If the online crack is not possible, it is possible to perform Pixie Dust Attack in offline.

comments.content: I think C is not correct cuz WEP is totally a different thing from vulnerable WPS. Out of all the answers here, I think A is correct. Even though handshakes are not easy to crack...
Also, option A says to crack encrypted password, which is not that easy to crack.

choices.D: Rainbow tables contain all possible password combinations, which can be used to perform a brute-force password attack to retrieve the password, which can then be used to connect to the WPA2-protected access point.
choices.A: Deauthentication attacks against an access point can allow an opportunity to capture the four-way handshake, which can be used to obtain and crack the encrypted password.
choices.B: Injection of customized ARP packets can generate many initialization vectors quickly, making it faster to crack the password, which can then be used to connect to the WPA2-protected access point.
choices.C: Weak implementations of the WEP can allow pin numbers to be guessed quickly, which can then be used to retrieve the password, which can then be used to connect to the WEP-protected access point.

questions.question_text: During a vulnerability assessment, the security consultant finds an XP legacy system that is running a critical business function. Which of the following mitigations is BEST for the consultant to conduct?

choices.A: Update to the latest Microsoft Windows OS.
choices.C: Segment the machine from the main network.
choices.B: Put the machine behind the WAF.

comments.content: Yes XP is most def Legacy!!! B will be wrong since no where does it say they are running a WEB based application. XP is most likely running some DOS based application if it's critical I bet. C is still your best choice
I will consider XP system as Legacy infrastructure

Do you have any reference againt it?
I have done some searching but I did find any document reference which says about the segmentation. 
I would go for B
https://securityintelligence.com/posts/secure-legacy-systems-cybersecurity/

discussion.content:
C. Segment the machine from the main network.

Seems most logical to restrict access to known users only.

Selected Answer: C
looks good to me

srsly? no a?
so call segmentation wouldnt save ur day but upgrading the os will do
Answer is C

B. https://securityintelligence.com/the-living-dead-how-to-protect-legacy-systems/

A single legacy system can be the gateway for malware to spread throughout a network.

You must also ensure that those systems are not directly accessible from the internet, and guarantee that any communication with them is restricted to minimal need. This can be achieved by placing these systems in their own network segment behind a router or firewall.
CompTIA loves to segment, that is the answer most of the time when it's pertaining to security, and it's the answer this time too.
C. segment out to be out-of-network if it must be used.. while behind a WAF pushes the legacy OS nearer to the internet...?!
